questions.text: Syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Familial Syndromes Associated With Pheochromocytoma and Extra-Adrenal Paragangliomas Gene:

  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2A (MEN-2A) (choice B)
  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2B (MEN-2B)
  • Neurofibromatosis, type 1 (NF1) (choice D)
  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) (choice C)
  • Hereditary paraganglioma 1
  • Hereditary paraganglioma 3
  • Hereditary paraganglioma 4
  • Polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome

PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA: Tumor of chromaffin cells that arises in the adrenal medulla.

Older adults

Can make catecholamines → hypertension → sustained or paroxysmal symptoms → headache, tachycardia, palpitation, sweating

The "rule of 10s".

  1. Ten percent of pheochromocytomas are extra-adrenal, occurring in sites such as the organs of Zuckerkandl and the carotid body.
  2. Ten percent of sporadic adrenal pheochromocytomas are bilateral
  3. Ten percent of adrenal pheochromocytomas are biologically malignant, defined by the presence of metastatic disease.
  4. Ten percent of adrenal pheochromocytomas are not associated with hypertension.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pheochromocytoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that arises from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla or extra-adrenal paraganglia. These tumors secrete excess catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and sometimes dopamine), leading to characteristic clinical symptoms and signs.

It is part of the spectrum of paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma syndrome and may occur sporadically or as part of hereditary syndromes such as MEN2, VHL, or NF1.

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Histological-appearance-of-pheochromocytoma-Hematoxylin-Eosin-staining-400_fig1_288661557

choices.text: It is the second most common cause of primary hyperthyroidism.
Most occur during the 7th and 8th decades of life.
Men are more commonly affected than women.
It is less commonly associated with MEN syndromes than primary chief cell hyperplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding parathyroid adenoma is TRUE?
questions.solution:
PRIMARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM

  • Common endocrine disorder
  • An important cause of hypercalcemia
  • Parathyroid lesions underlying hyperfunction is as follows:
    • Adenoma: 85% to 95%
    • Primary hyperplasia (diffuse or nodular): 5% to 10%
    • Parathyroid carcinoma: ~1%
  • Older adults (choice B)
  • F>M (4:1) (choice C)
  • The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary sporadic parathyroid adenoma (choice A) (not the second most common)
  • The genetic syndromes associated with familial parathyroid adenomas include
    • MEN-1
    • MEN-2
    • MEN-4
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Approximately 30% to 35% of sporadic parathyroid tumors have somatic mutations of the MEN1 gene, a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 11q13, with loss of heterozygosity (LOH) of the second allele.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Parathyroid Adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that causes excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
SECONDARY HYPERPARATHYROIDISM

  • Chronic hypocalcemia → leads to compensatory overactivity of the parathyroid glands.
  • Causes:
    • Renal failure (the most common cause) (chronic renal insufficiency → decreased phosphate excretion → hypophosphatemia)
    • Inadequate dietary intake of calcium
    • Steatorrhea
    • Vitamin D deficiency
  • The elevated serum phosphate levels → depress serum calcium levels → thereby stimulate parathyroid gland activity.
  • loss of renal substance reduces the availability of α1-hydroxylase (Necessary for the synthesis of the active form of vitamin D) → reduced intestinal absorption of calcium
  • Because vitamin D has suppressive effects on parathyroid growth and PTH secretion, its deficiency compounds the hyperparathyroidism in renal failure.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is the compensatory overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to chronic stimulation of the parathyroid glands in response to hypocalcemia or hyperphosphatemia, typically caused by an underlying condition.

questions.text: 50-year-old man presents with a mass of the right adrenal gland and a history of recent hypertension that has been difficult to control. An adrenal mass is resected with the following histology (see image). Which immunostain will most likely be negative from the following?
questions.solution:
PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA: Tumor of chromaffin cells that arises in the adrenal medulla.

  • Older adults
  • Can make catecholamines → hypertension → sustained or paroxysmal symptoms → headache, tachycardia, palpitation, sweating
  • Immunohistochemical markers:
    • Vimentin, chromogranin A and synaptophysin, while the sustentacular cells surrounding the nests of tumor cells react strongly for S 100.
    • Inhibin is negative in pheochromocytomas but is positive in adrenal cortical adenomas and in most adrenal cortical carcinomas.
    • Pheochromocytomas are usually negative for cytokeratin but can be positive in up to 25% of cases.

Microscopic Features:

  1. Zellballen Pattern:
    • Tumor cells arranged in nests or clusters called "zellballen", separated by a rich vascular stroma.
    • This arrangement is characteristic of neuroendocrine tumors.
  2. Cell Morphology:
    • Tumor cells are polygonal to spindle-shaped.
    • Abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm (due to catecholamine-containing granules).
    • Uniform, round to oval nuclei with a "salt-and-pepper" chromatin pattern.
  3. Vascular Stroma:
    • Prominent vascular network surrounding the zellballen.
  4. Capsule Invasion:
    • Presence of capsular and vascular invasion helps distinguish benign from malignant pheochromocytoma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pheochromocytoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that arises from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla or extra-adrenal paraganglia. These tumors secrete excess catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and sometimes dopamine), leading to characteristic clinical symptoms and signs.

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Histological-appearance-of-pheochromocytoma-Hematoxylin-Eosin-staining-400_fig1_288661557

choices.text: Possible local recurrence with continued pressure-related damage to adjacent structures

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with headache and bilateral hemianopsia, as well as evidence of increased intracranial pressure and diabetes insipidus. Suprasellar calcification is apparent on radiographic examination. Resection of the contents of the sella turcica and parasellar area yields a large tumor with histology closely resembling the enamel organ of the embryonic tooth. The most likely outcome of this lesion is
questions.solution:
CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA

  • Benign, epithelial tumors derived from embryonic remnants of Rathke's pouch
  • Does not invade or metastasize
  • Usually present with mass effect (visual disturbance, headache or endocrine changes)
  • Recurrence due to incomplete resection
  • Local growth and tissue destruction result in both anterior and posterior pituitary dysfunction, and a patient often presents with signs of increased intracranial pressure → hydrocephalus → bilateral hemianopsia (loss of peripheral visual fields) due to impingement on the optic chiasm.
  • Diabetes insipidus is also frequent.
  • Radiograph: Calcification

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

ADAMANTINOMATOUS CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA

  • Age
    • Bimodal age distribution (1st & 5th decades)
  • Gross
    • Multicystic areas
  • Micro scopy
    • Basallayer with basal palisading
  • Micro scopy
    • Stellate reticulum (loose background), whorls, "wet Keratin", calcification, cholesterol clefts
  • IHC/molecular
    • Nuclear expression of Beta catenin
  • Image

PAPILLARY CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA

  • Age
    • Exclusively in adults
  • Gross
    • Solid mass
  • Micro scopy
    • Resembles a squamous papilloma: non keratizing epithelium and fibrovascular cores.
  • Micro scopy
    • No stellate reticulum, wet keratin, or calcification
  • IHC/molecular
    • BRAF V600E mutation, p63+, ck 5/6
  • Image

questions.text: Which variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma may not display the typical nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Histologic variants/types of PAPILLARY THYROID CARCINOMA:

  1. Papillary microcarcinoma
  2. Encapsulated variant
  3. Follicular variant
  4. Diffuse sclerosing variant
  5. Oncocytic variant
  6. Tall cell carcinoma
  7. Columnar cell carcinoma
  8. Cribriform morular variant
  9. Hobnail variant

Columnar cell carcinoma:

  • It is characterized by thin Papillae or glandular-like spaces lined by an epithelium
  • Prominent nuclear stratification;
  • Clear cytoplasm(sometimes with subnuclear vacuolization) rather than acidophilic as in the tall cell variant;
  • squamoid whorls or morules ±
  • The nuclei usually lack the optically clear appearance, grooves, and pseudoinclusions seen in papillary carcinoma and all of its other variants, henceforth it has been questioned whether columnar cell carcinoma is really a variant of papillary carcinoma, as opposed to a different tumor type despite its highly papillary architecture.
  • Immunohistochemical markers:
    • Thyroglobulin - variable expression
    • Ki67 - High
    • CDX2 + (should be differentiated from metastatic colonic adenocarcinoma)
    • Beta catenin -
    • p53 - weak/negative

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Columnar cell carcinoma (CCC) of the thyroid is a rare and aggressive variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) characterized by columnar-shaped tumor cells.

Microscopic Features:

  • Tumor cells are tall and columnar with basal nuclei and pale cytoplasm.
  • Cells are arranged in papillary, trabecular, or solid patterns.
  • Nuclear features of PTC may be less prominent.

Reference: https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/thyroidcolumnarvariant.html

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prognostic factor of the papillary thyroid cancer?
questions.solution:
Prognostic factors of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

The overall survival of patients with papillary carcinoma is excellent

  1. Age. Poor outcome - after the age of 40 years.
  2. Sex. Females are said to have a better prognosis than males
  3. Extrathyroidal extension. Worst outcome
  4. Microscopic variants - columbarium carcinoma, hobnail variant etc have poor outcome
  5. History of previous irradiation.
  6. Tumor size. A rough inverse correlation is present between tumor size and prognosis.
  7. Capsule and margins. Tumors that are encapsulated and/or have pushing margins have a better outcome than the others.
  8. Multicentricity. Patients in whom this is a prominent feature have a greater incidence of metastasis and less chance of disease-free survival.
  9. Lymph node metastases. Extranodal tumor extension may be an indicator of a greater likelihood of distant metastases and poor prognosis
  10. Distant metastases. Metastases to lung have an adverse influence on prognosis; also in skeletal system.
  11. Poorly differentiated, squamous, or anaplastic foci. These features have a markedly detrimental effect on prognosis.
  12. Grading.
  13. TERT promoter mutations have been associated with poor prognosis
  14. BRAF p.V600E: poor outcome

Factors not generally found to correlate with prognosis are:

  • Relative proportion of papillae and follicles;
  • Presence or amount of fibrosis;
  • Presence or amount of squamous metaplasia or psammoma bodies
  • Microvessel density

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Papillary thyroid cancer generally has an excellent prognosis with a 10-year survival rate exceeding 95% in most cases.

Prognosis is heavily influenced by age, tumor size, histological variant, and presence of distant metastases.

questions.text: A palpable mass is noted in the right lobe of thyroid of a 47 year old man. Thyroidectomy specimen shows the following microscopic features. Which of the following is not TRUE about this case?
questions.solution:
Between 50% and 80% of conventional Papillary thyroid carcinomas harbor Gain-of-function mutations in the BRAF gene. (Choice A)

Medullary thyroid carcinomas:

  • Occur in multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 2 (MEN-2) (choice B)
  • Frequent RET mutations, rare RAS mutations.
  • Malignant tumor of the thyroid with parafollicular C-cells differentiation
  • Painless mass
  • Frequent LN metastases at presentation with elevated serum calcitonin
  • Microscopy:
    • Growth patterns: Solid, lobular, trabecular and/or insular
    • Tumor cells can appear: Round, polygonal, plasmacytoid or spindled.
    • Nuclei are "neuroendocrine" (round, speckled "salt and pepper") with occasional pseudoinclusions.
    • Granular Eosinophilic cytoplasm
    • Amyloid stroma (choice D)
    • IHC:
      • Calcitonin (most specific) +
      • Neuroendocrine markers (synaptophysin, chromogranin) +
      • TTF-1 +
      • PAX-8 +
      • Thyroglobulin Negative (choice C)
    • Prognosis: Intermediate aggressive behavior

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Medullary thyroid cancer is a form of thyroid carcinoma which originates from the parafollicular cells (C cells), which produce the hormone calcitonin.

questions.text: An autopsy is performed on an 8 year old child with Diabetes Mellitus of recent onset who has died following a bike accident. Which of the following autopsy findings would favor the diagnosis of type 1 diabetes as contrasted to type 2 diabetes?
questions.solution:
Choice A, C & D are seen in type 2 diabetes melitus

Nodular Glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/KIMMELSTIEL-WILSON DISEASE. (Choice C)

  • Highly specific lesion of type 2 diabetes
  • It consists of PAS positive nodules of matrix situated in the periphery of the glomeruli.
  • Associated with prominent accumulation of hyaline material in capillary loops and Bowman's capsule known as "fibrin caps" and "capsular drops"

ARMANI EBSTEIN CELLS (choice A)

  • In uncontrolled diabetes there is presence of glucosuria resulting in glycogen accumulation in Proximal Tubular cells. (Called as Armani Ebstein cells)

Diabetic Retinopathy (choice D)

  • The most profound ocular changes of diabetes are seen in the retina. The retinal vasculopathy of diabetes mellitus can be classified into background (preproliferative) diabetic retinopathy and proliferative diabetic retinopathy

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Nodular glomerulosclerosis characterized by eosinophilic, PAS-positive nodules in the mesangium, pathognomonic for diabetic nephropathy.

Pathogenesis:

  • Chronic hyperglycemia → advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) → mesangial expansion and basement membrane thickening.
  • Increased mesangial matrix deposition → formation of nodules.

Reference: https://www.endocrinepractice.org/article/S1530-891X%2820%2942205-0/abstract

questions.text: An adult man having generalized increase in body size with disproportionately long arms and legs, and specific facial features (Shown in the first image). On radiological examination, patient shows a mass present in the sella turcica and anterior clinoid processes extending into suprasellar region. Histopathological examination of the mass shows the following microscopic features. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
PITUITARY ADENOMA:

  • Most common tumor of sella turcica.
  • Usually adults.
  • Neoplasm of anterior pituitary hormone-producing cells.
  • Benign, but can invade adjacent structures
  • Microscopic features: (shown in image)
    • Monomorphic neuroendocrine cells.
    • Round nuclei
    • Patterns: diffuse, papillary and trabecular
    • Eosinophilic or basophilic cytoplasm
    • Perivascular orientation
  • IHC stains: Synaptophysin+, Chromogranin+, s100-
  • On touch preparation: cellular, discohesive, homogenous neuroendocrine proliferation
  • Subclassify by HORMONE SECRETION, use IHC pamnel: Growth hormone (GH), prolactin, TSH-beta, ACTH, FSH-beta, LH-beta, Alpha subunit
  • FUNCTIONING ADENOMA → secrete hormone → often present early with symptoms/tumor syndrome.
  • Silent adenoma → do not secrete hormone, but still stain with hormone IHC.
  • Non functioning adenoma → present with mass Effect. Press on optic chiasm → bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia, headache.
  • Usually sporadic but can occur in MEN1, DICER1 etc.
  • Treatment: Transsphenoidal resection, pharmacotherapy or radiation
  • Types of Pituitary adenoma:
    • Lactotroph adenoma
    • Somatotroph adenoma
    • Corticotroph adenoma
    • Gonadotroph adenoma
    • Thyrotroph adenoma
    • Null cell adenoma
    • Plurihormonal adenoma

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Growth hormone (GH)-secreting somatotroph adenomas are the second most common type of functioning pituitary adenoma, and cause GIGANTISM in children and ACROMEGALY in adults.

questions.text: Which of the following type of pituitary adenoma is associated with Cushing's disease?
questions.solution:
Excess production of ACTH by FUNCTIONING CORTICOTROPH ADENOMAS leads to adrenal hypersecretion of cortisol and the development of hypercortisolism (also known as Cushing syndrome).

  • Large destructive pituitary adenomas can develop in patients after surgical removal of the adrenal glands for treatment of Cushing syndrome. This condition, known as Nelson syndrome, occurs because of loss of the inhibitory effect of adrenal corticosteroids on a corticotroph microadenoma.
  • Because the adrenals are absent in persons with Nelson syndrome, hypercortisolism does not develop.
  • The rest of the choices are not associated with Cushing's disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Excess production of ACTH by FUNCTIONING CORTICOTROPH ADENOMAS leads to adrenal hypersecretion of cortisol and the development of hypercortisolism (also known as Cushing syndrome).

questions.text: Which of the following statement is FALSE about Pituitary blastoma?
questions.solution:
PITUITARY BLASTOMA

  • Rare developmental tumor seen in neonatal period (choice D)
  • 3 components:
    1. Small chromophobic and undifferentiated blastema-like cells
    2. Larger patternless secretory cells with round nuclieand abundant cytoplasm
    3. Cuboidal to columnar cells forming glandular like structures
  • IHC: ACTH+, Prolactin-, TSH-, FSH-, LH-
  • Associated with Cushing's disease (choice A)
  • Molecular: DICER1 mutation (choice B)
  • Relatively poor prognosis (choice C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pituitary blastoma is A rare, aggressive embryonal tumor of the pituitary gland, typically occurring in infants and young children. It arises from primitive pituitary progenitor cells.

Genetics:

  • Associated with DICER1 mutations, which are crucial in RNA interference and microRNA processing.

Clinical Features:

  • Neonatal-onset Cushing's syndrome (due to excess ACTH production).
  • Mass effect symptoms (e.g., headache, visual disturbances, hydrocephalus in larger tumors).
  • Hypopituitarism in some cases.

questions.text: Choose the INCORRECT statement regarding pineal gland and it's tumors from the following.
questions.solution:
PINEAL GLAND

  • Pinecone-shaped organ (hence its name) (choice B)
  • Weighs 100 to 180 mg
  • Lying between the superior colliculi at the base of the brain
  • Composed of a loose, neuroglial stroma enclosing nests of epithelial-appearing pineocytes, cells with photosensory and neuroendocrine functions (hence the designation of the pineal gland as the "third eye").
  • Silver impregnation stain: Reveal that these cells have long, slender processes reminiscent of primitive neuronal precursors intermixed with the processes of astrocytic cells.
  • The principal secretory product of the pineal gland is MELATONIN, which is involved in the control of circadian rhythms (choice A), including the sleep-wake cycle, hence the popular use of melatonin for the treatment of jet lag.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pineocytoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not a microscopic nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
PAPILLARY THYROID CARCINOMA

  • Malignant tumor with follicular epithelial cell differentiation
  • Most common form of thyroid carcinoma in both adults and children
  • Defined by distinct nuclear features and either papillary or solid/trabecular architecture, or invasive growth in follicular patterned tumors
  • Risk factor - Ionizing radiation
  • Molecular alteration - BRAF (Most common), RET, RAS, TERT promoter → often mutually exclusive → MAPK activation

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Histology of Papillary thyroid cancer:

  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Empty-appearing nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin.
  • Nuclear Grooves: Longitudinal infoldings of nuclear membranes.
  • Intranuclear Cytoplasmic Inclusions: Cytoplasm invaginated into the nucleus, giving a "pseudo-inclusion" appearance.

Reference: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Thyroid_papillary_carcinoma_histopathology_%283%29.jpg

choices.text: Dense lymphoid and plasmacytic infiltrate with large follicles and prominent germinal centers
Lymphoid infiltrate consisting primarily of B cells versus T cells
Primarily IgA containing plasma cells with lambda light chains

questions.text: The inflammatory infiltrate seen in Hashimlto Thyroiditis is best characterized by:
questions.solution:
Hashimoto's thyroiditis

  • The two main abnormalities:
    • Lymphocytic infiltration of the stroma
    • Oxyphilic change of the follicular epithelium
  • The lymphoid tissue is distributed within and around the lobules, and it invariably exhibits large follicles with prominent germinal centers. Lymphocytes predominate, T cells predominating over B cells. Plasma cells, histiocytes, and scattered Intrafollicular multinucleated giant cells are also present.
  • A dense infiltrate of lymphoid and plasma cells with follicles and germinal centers is typical for Hashimoto thyroiditis.
  • The lymphoid cells consist of a roughly equal ratio of T and B cells.
  • In contrast to Riedel thyroiditis, plasma cells in Hashimoto thyroiditis express kappa to lambda light chains 2:1 (vs the 70% lambda expression in fibrosing thyroiditis) and only-15% of the immunocytic population consists of IgA-containing plasma cells (versus 45% in Riedel thyroiditis).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

Most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas where iodine levels are sufficient.

Gradual thyroid failure due to autoimmune destruction of thyroid gland

It is Characterized by:

  1. Diffuse goitrous enlargement of the thyroid
  2. Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland
  3. Presence of thyroid autoantibodies.
